review.title: A Hybrid Architecture for Multi-Party Conversational Systems
review.abstract: Multi-party Conversational Systems are systems with natural language interaction between one or more people or systems. From the moment that an utterance is sent to a group, to the moment that it is replied in the group by a member, several activities must be done by the system: utterance understanding, information search, reasoning, among others. In this paper we present the challenges of designing and building multi-party conversational systems, the state of the art, our proposed hybrid architecture using both rules and machine learning and some insights after implementing and evaluating one on the finance domain.

sections.heading: 3.5 Platforms
sections.text: Regarding the current platforms to support the development of conversation systems, we can divide them into three types: platforms to plug in chatbots, to create chatbots and to create service chatbots. Platforms to plug in chatbots provide tools to integrate into another system, such as Slack7. Chatbots must receive and send messages in a certain way, which depends on the API, and there is no support for actual support in building chatbots with natural speech comprehension. Chatbots create platforms mainly offer tools to add and train intentions along with the specification of dialogue flow and extraction of some units, without support for reasoning. Once the models are trained and the dialogue flow specified, the chatbots are able to respond to the received intention. Platforms to create service chatbots offer the same functionality as the last one and also provide support in defining the current actions summarized in the table 8 of current chatbots, if they are executed in accordance with the categories.

sections.heading: 4.1 Workflow
sections.text: Figure 2 shows that a statement is made in a chat group at the time when a response is generated in the same chat group when the case occurs. One or more people may be in the chat group, while one or more chatbots are also sent. There is a hub that is responsible for sending messages to every member of the group when the case occurs. The flow begins when a statement is sent to the chat group and, if allowed, is broadcast. Many or no interactions can be enforced at this level depending on the application. Here, a rule can be a prohibition, obligation or permission to send a statement to the chat group. Once the statement is broadcast, a chatbot must handle the statement. To handle it properly, the chatbot analyzes the statement with multiple parsers during the parsing phase.

sections.heading: 4.1.2 Dependency Parsing
sections.text: Dependence is the notion that linguistic units, such as words, are connected to each other by directed links. (Finite) verb is assumed to be the structural center of the sentence structure. All other syntactic units (words) are either directly or indirectly connected to the verb in relation to directed links, which are called dependencies. The result of this one-to-one correspondence is that dependency programs are word (or morpho-) grammars. All that exists are the elements and dependencies that connect the elements into a structure. Dependency grammar (DG) is a class of modern syntactic theories, all based on the dependency relationship.

sections.heading: 4.1.3 Frame Parsing
sections.text: In this module, the generated dependency tree is used along with a set of rules to extract information that is stored in context using the frame-based approach, which fills the slots of the frame with the values extracted from the dialog. Frames are like forms and slots like fields. Using the conceptual model of knowledge, the fields are represented by the elements entities and features. In the dependency tree example, the entity would be the implicit concept: the investment option, and the feature is the implicit concept: initial amount - 10,000. Since the goal is to invest, and more entities are needed to do so (i.e. fields to be filled), the next node in the Intention Flow tree would return an expression asking the user for the investment time if he / she has not provided it. This module could be implemented with different approaches depending on the domain, but will be tree searching algorithms to perform tree parsing.

sections.text: This component is responsible for implementing the behavior of the action class. sections.heading: 5 Architecture Implementation and Evaluation
sections.text: This section presents an implementation of the conceptual architecture presented in the previous section. After many refactorings, a framework called SABIA (Speech-Act-Based Intelligent Agents Framework) was developed and the application CognIA (Cognitive Investment Advisor) was developed as an instance of the SABIA framework. Afterwards, we present the accuracy and some automated tests of this implementation.

sections.heading: 5.1 Speech-Act-based Intelligent Agents Framework
sections.text: SABIA was developed based on the Akka intermediate10. Akka is a toolkit and runtime that implements the actor model on the JVM. Akka's features such as contemporaneity, distributed computing, resilience and message delivery were inspired by Erlangen's actor model [45]. The actor model is a mathematical model of concurrent computation that treats "actors" as universal primitives of concurrent computation. In response to a message it receives, an actor can: make local decisions, create more actors, send more messages and determine how he responds to the next message received. Actors can change the private state, 10http: / / akka.iobut can only influence each other through messages (to avoid the need for keys). Akka middleware manages the actors "life cycle, and actors look for their name, locally or remotely.

sections.heading: 5.2.6 Intention Classifier
sections.text: Given the fact that there is no public record of financial intentions in Portuguese, we have used the incremental approach to create our own training set for the Intent Classifier. First, we applied the Wizard of the Oz Method and from this study we collected a series of 124 questions that users asked. Next, after these questions were manually classified into a series of intention classes, and used to train the first version of the system, this sentence was increased both in terms of the number of classes and samples per class, resulting in a training set of 37 intentions, and a total of 415 samples, with samples per class from 3 to 37. We have defined our classification method based on properties extracted from word vectors. Word vectors consist of a way to encode the semantic meaning of the words based on their frequency of common occurrence.

sections.heading: 5.3 Intention Classifier Accuracy
sections.text: In Table 15 we present the comparison of some different classifications on the first version of the training set, i.e. on the scale used to integrate the first classifier into the system. Broadly speaking, the 1NN classifier was able to achieve a level of accuracy higher than other known classifiers, such as Logistic Regression and Naïve Bayes, which shows that 1NN is suitable as a development classifier. Nevertheless, an SVM can perform considerably better than 1NN and achieve accuracies about 12 percentage points higher, showing that this type of basic classifier is a better choice when the system is stable enough. It is worth noting that these results take into account the one-sided validation process, as the number of samples in some classes is very low. As we have already mentioned, the use of a 1NN classifier has enabled the system developer to easily add new target classes and samples, so that the system could present a new class with a great understanding of 6N or very high accuracy actions.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: In this article, we explored the challenges of MPCS engineering and presented a hybrid conceptual architecture and its implementation with a financial advisory system. We are currently developing this architecture to support the specification of decoupled interaction standards, and we are also developing a multi-party governance service that uses this specification to force the exchange of compliant statements. We are also exploring a micro-service implementation of SABIA to increase its scalability and performance so that thousands of members can join the system within thousands of conversations.

metadata.abstractText: Multi-party Conversational Systems are systems with natural language interaction between one or more people or systems. From the moment that an utterance is sent to a group, to the moment that it is replied in the group by a member, several activities must be done by the system: utterance understanding, information search, reasoning, among others. In this paper we present the challenges of designing and building multiparty conversational systems, the state of the art, our proposed hybrid architecture using both norms and machine learning and some insights after implementing and evaluating one on the finance domain.
